thread.title_full: Melbourne broker Aizaz Hassan pleads guilty in $110 million home loan fraud

author: Sarah Danckert
title: Melbourne broker Aizaz Hassan pleads guilty in $110 million home loan fraud
text:
Twelve Australian banks were caught up in the home loan fraud ring. Photo: Louis Douvis
Melbourne mortgage broker Aizaz Hassan has pleaded guilty to one charge of conspiring to defraud financial institutions after he drew up loan applications worth approximately $110 million using fake documents.
Twelve Australian banks were caught up in the home loan fraud ring including Commonwealth Bank of Australia, ANZ Bank, Westpac and National Australia Bank.
St George, Bankwest, Adelaide Bank, Bank of Queensland, Citibank, Pepper Home Loans, Mortgage Choice and Suncorp were also embroiled in the alleged scam.
Three other people have been charged. Photo: Jim Rice
The charges were laid after an investigation by the Australian Securities and Investment Commission found over 300 home loans worth $110 million had been drawn up using fake documents between April 2008 and December 2011.
Advertisement The fake documents included bank statements, pay slips, citizenship certificates and statutory declarations.
Three other people have been charged for their alleged involvement in the home loan scheme.
Aizaz Hassan has pleaded guilty.
Another man was also arrested in January 2015 and charged with conspiracy to defraud financial institutions. He is yet to enter a plea.
Another alleged accomplice has also pled not guilty two charges of using a false document and obtaining a financial advantage by deception.
A fourth person, Mohamed Radhi Maki Ebrahim Ahmed of Victoria pleaded guilty in March to one charge of conspiring to defraud financial institutions for his involvement in the scheme.
ASIC's investigation homed in on little known Footscray-based finance house Myra Home Loan, trading as Myra Financial Services.
Mr Hassan entered the guilty plea during an appearance at the Melbourne Magistrates' Court on September 9, 2015.
He was arrested and charged in January 2015. However, he only stopped being a mortgage broker after the media contacted his then employer.
Mr Hassan is currently on bail and is required to appear at the County Court at Melbourne on October 14, 2015.
